articleinfo.title: Mindquarry Collaboration Server Feature Documentation
articleinfo.subtitle: Description of the features provided by the Mindquarry Team Suite

abstract.para: This document describes the features of the Mindquarry Team Suite as well as their purpose and usage.

section.title: Feature Description
section.para: The following sections describes the features provided by the Mindquarry Open Source Collaboration Server in Version 1.0. The web application and web interface is seperated into several components (teamspace, workspace, wiki and tasks); a desktop client connects the desktop computer with the server for things best done on the computer (like files of the workspaces); the client uses a public HTTP Rest API.

section.title: General
section.para: The overall system has the following basics:

listitem.para: Users have different views on the system, ie. depending in which teams they are. Each user account represents a single human being, identified by a unique user id, name and by a photo wherever possible in the user interface. The user profile also contains an email address and a description of the user's skills. There is a special user with id "admin" for administrative work.

Teams represent the basic structure for all data in the Mindquarry system. They depict people working together on something (you can call it projects). Each team has its own workspace, wiki and task area. A team has a unique id, a name and a short description.

section.title: Web interface commons
section.para: The following common features are provided by the Mindquarry Collaboration Server web interface:

listitem.para: Users login and logout with their user id and a password. All authentication is done via HTTP Basic Auth, which allows REST-style clients like the Desktop client to use the same authentication mechanism. The web user interface provides a familar form-based login which hides HTTP authentication. If a direct link is clicked when the user is not logged in (e.g. sent via email), the login form will redirect to the link on successful login. The name of the logged-in user will be displayed in the top-right of each page with a log out link next to it.

In the first version authorization is very simple and non-configurable: users have full read and write access to the teamspaces they belong to, but cannot create teams or other users. Creating teams and users is only possible with the admin account.

A search box is visible on all pages in the top-left which allows to enter simple search words and quickly returns the result in a small popup window. In Version 1.0 only wiki pages and tasks areas are searched, the results are grouped accordingly.

section.title: Teams
section.para: The Teamspace Component is the adminstrative area where the teams and users that collaborate are managed for the system:

listitem.para: The "admin" user can create a user from the teamspace overview page. All basic data (id, password, photo, first name, surname, email and skill description) can be entered in a dialog.
Each user can change his own profile via a click on his user id displayed in the top left. The user id cannot be changed.
The "admin" user can create a new team from the teamspace overview page.
All users of a team and the "admin" user can add and remove members to their team. Adding a user to a team is only possible by the "admin" user in the first place.
All users of a team can change the name and the description of the team at any time. The team id cannot be changed.

section.title: Tasks
section.para: The Tasks Component allows to manage any kind of work tasks and their relations:

listitem.para: A task is described by a number of fields, where only two are required (title and status). The other fields can be added on demand.
(required) The short description of the task, visible as link on other pages (task lists, search results, etc.)
(required) Either new, running, paused or done to indicate the current general status of the task.
(optional) A text with additional information complementing the title. Displayed on the task list page.
(optional) A date connected with the task. Could be the deadline, for example.
(optional) A long, rich-text formatted description of the task.

(optional) A list of people/users connected to this task. Each person has a role, which can be freely defined. E.g. "someuser" with role "responsible". People can be choosen from the list of users of the current team.
(optional) A checkbox to indicate that this task is no longer under active use and should be in the archive (not yet in place).
(optional) A list of dependencies to other tasks of this team. As with people, the role can be freely defined. Typcial dependencies are "depends on", "duplicate of", "before" etc.
All users of a team can create a task. The task initially has the two required fields, title and status. The unique id for a task is an automatically calculated consecutive number.

All users of a team can modify a task. A task cannot be deleted, only archived. Editing is possible by clicking on one field to edit this field only or by clicking on "Edit all" to edit all fields and to change which fields should be present.
A list of tasks for a teamspace.

A filter is an intelligent list of tasks (report) which filters only specific tasks according to rules. A rule might be "Field status is running" to give all currently running tasks. Filters belong to a teamspace and filter the tasks of that teamspace. Filters can be saved under a descriptive name.
A filter can be viewed in which the filtered list of tasks is recalculated. The rules can be changed.
The list of filters for the task area of a teamspace are displayed on the overview and the task list page.

section.title: Wiki
section.para: The Wiki Component provides a wiki for each team to store ideas, notes, any kind of fluent knowledge:

listitem.para: A wiki page consists of a title and a content, which is a rich-text field. Editing is fully WYSIWYG, there is no special wiki syntax.

A wiki page can be created via a click on the "create page" button or by typing a not-yet-existing name of the page in the URL. In the first case the unique name of a wiki page is automatically derived from the title.

The title and the content can be changed at any time. The unique name cannot be changed. Editing is possible by clicking on the title or content to edit those specifically or by clicking on "Edit all" to edit both.

It is possible to add hyperlinks to other wiki pages in the same wiki in the content field. There are two buttons, that can be used after marking a piece of text that should become the link. One creates a link to the page name based on the selected text, the other presents a dialog where a list of the wiki pages is shown or an external URL (starting with http:// or https://) can be entered.
A fixed "Start" page is automatically created and can be reached via the wiki overview page. It should be used as the entry point for the wiki.

section.title: Workspace Management
section.para: The Workspace Component allows to view the files and the structure of the working files shared by each each time online:

listitem.para: The directory structure of the versioned workspace can be browsed. The latest version number, timestamp, change comment, name and photo of the user who made the change will be displayed.
Old versions can be browsed.
Workspace files can be downloaded, either displayed in the browser if they are text files or saved on the local computer if they are binary files.
A link to an RSS feed provides notification of changed files for RSS readers.

section.title: Desktop Client
section.para: The Mindquarry Desktop Client runs on the computer of a user and improves the work by connecting to the server:

listitem.para: The client is an unobtrusive but always running application that will reside in the "tray" of the operating system (this depends on the actual OS). Clicking on the tray icon will show a small window with all important information.

Automatically synchronizes the workspaces for the teams the user belongs to into a directory on the local hard drive. Any changes done by the team members will be "downloaded" into the local directory (after a notification) and any changes done by the user can be shared with the rest of the team on demand.
A list of a user's task is displayed in the small window.
A task can be stopped from within the window.

section.title: HTTP REST Client API
section.para: There is a REST-style interface for computer-based clients to exchange information with the Mindquarry Collaboration Server. All data is in XML formats which incorporate usage of hyperlinks. Authentication must be done with a valid user account via HTTP basic authentication for each request:

listitem.para: The list of tasks for a teamspace can be retrieved via a HTTP GET on the URL /tasks/<team-id>/
A task including all data can be retrieved via a HTTP GET on the URL /tasks/<team-id>/<task-id>.xml
A new task can be created by sending a task in the correct XML format with an HTTP PUT on the URL /tasks/<team-id>/new
A task can be changed/overwritten with an HTTP PUT including the new XML data on the URL /tasks/<team-id>/<task-id>.xml
The list of wiki pages for a teamspace can be retrieved via a HTTP GET on the URL /wiki/<team-id>/
A wiki page XML data can be retrieved via a HTTP GET on the URL /wiki/<team-id>/<pagename>
A new wiki page can be created by sending a page in the correct XML format with an HTTP PUT on the URL /wiki/<team-id>/new or by writing to a non-existing page name /wiki/<team-id>/<new-pagename>
A wiki page can be changed/overwritten with an HTTP PUT including the new XML data on the URL /wiki/<team-id>/<pagename>
